columns.text: In this exercise, we are going to learn about abandonment value.

To start with, let us define abandonment value. 

**Abandonment value** is the amount of cash the firm would have earned if the investment is abandoned. 

In making a decision if the investment should be abandoned or not, the concept of net present value is used. 

The **net present value (NPV)** is the present value of initial investment or cash outflow less the present value of the cash inflows.

If the NPV is lower than the salvage or residual value of the investment, then it can be liquidated.

Here are the parameters to solve the requirement: 


|Given | | 
|--|--| 
|Annual cash flow |$397,600 | 
|Discount rate (r) |14% | 
|Initial investment |$1,800,000 | 
|Present Value Factor |5.2161 |

## Requirement A

We are required to solve the net present value of the new project. 

The net present value is solved as follows: 

  

$$\textbf{NPV}=\text{PV of Cash Inflows}-\text{Initial Investment}$$

The initial investment is deducted from the present value of cash inflows to determine the net present value.

Whereas, the present value of cash inflows is solved as follows: 

  

$$\textbf{PV of Cash Inflows}=\text{Cash Inflow}\times\text{PV Factor}$$

The cash inflows are multiplied by the present value factor to determine the present value of cash inflows.

To start with, let us solve the present value of the cash inflows using the equation in Step 5: 

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{PV of Cash Inflows}&=\$397,600\times5.2161\\[15pt]
&=\$2,073,921.36
\end{aligned}$$
 
Thus, the present value of cash inflows is $2,073,921.36.

## Requirement 2

We are asked to solve the level of sales it is acceptable to abandon the project. 

The level of sales it makes sense to abandon the project is solved as follows: 

$$\textbf{Sales}=\text{Salvage Value}\times\left[\frac{\text{r}}{\left[1-\left(\frac{1}{1+\text{r}}\right)^\text{n}\right]}\right]$$

Where : 

 r - Discount rate\
n- Number of periods

Using the equation in Step 8, the level of sales at which the project can be abandoned is solved as follows:

 

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Sales}&=\$1,200,000\times\left[\frac{0.14}{1-\left(\frac{1}{1+0.14}\right)^9}\right]\\[20pt]
&=\$1,200,000\times\left[\frac{0.14}{1-\left(\frac{1}{1.14}\right)^9}\right]\\[20pt]
&=\$1,200,000\times\left[\frac{0.14}{1-\left(0.8772\right)^9}\right]\\[20pt]
&=\$1,200,000\times\left(\frac{0.14}{1-0.3075}\right)\\[20pt]
&=\$1,200,000\times\left(\frac{0.14}{0.6925}\right)\\[20pt]
&=\$1,200,000\times.2022\\[20pt]
&=\boxed{\$242,640}
\end{aligned}$$

The level of sales is at $242,640 it makes sense to abandon the project.

## Requirement 3

We are asked to explain how the $1,200,000 abandonment value can be identified as an opportunity cost.

**Opportunity cost** is the forgone benefit or the loss of a potential benefit from choosing an alternative over another option. 

The price of $1,200,000 at which the project can be sold is viewed as an opportunity cost because this amount can be earned instead of choosing to continue the project.
